text:
In order to grow a restaurant chain quickly you need a shit ton of capital. And restaurant chains use this hack called sale leasebacks to unlock that capital. 

Most restaurants are sitting on a goldmine: their real estate. The smartest operators are turning that real estate into capital without losing control of their business. 

A sale leaseback is when a restaurant sells its owned real estate to an investor, then immediately leases it back under a long-term agreement. That unlocks cash while letting the restaurant keep operating in the same location.

How are some recent examples of groups using this to grow:

🍔 Meritage Hospitality (2nd-largest Wendy’s franchisee) sold 48 stores in 2020–21 for $109M, using the proceeds to build new units and pay down credit lines.

🍕 Papa John’s (2024) sold two commissary kitchens for $46.7M with 17-year triple-net leases and 2.75% annual rent bumps. That plugged a $27M cash shortfall and booked a $41M gain.

🍗 Yummy Inc. (a large Yum! Brands franchisee) recapitalized 20 Taco Bell & KFC units this way, stabilizing operations and funding growth within a year.

🍟 Red Robin sold 28 sites for ~$73M in 2023–24 to Essential Properties Realty Trust, cutting debt by $49M in one year.

Why investors love QSR (quick-service restaurant) real estate:

1️⃣ E-commerce resistant – You can’t “Amazon” a burger. Even during the pandemic, drive-thru and takeout kept revenue flowing and rent paid. Compare that with malls and shopping real-estate that’s been hammered as consumers buy entirely online

2️⃣ Triple-net stability – Tenants pay property taxes, utilities, insurance, and common area fees. Landlords collect rent (often with 1–2% annual bumps) without worrying about other costs

3️⃣ Creditworthy tenants – Corporate-guaranteed McDonald’s and Chick-fil-A sites have sold at 4.0–4.5% cap rates. That’s seen as lower risk than a mom-and-pop shop that could miss rent payments

The bottom line: Sale-leasebacks let operators fund expansion, remodels, acquisitions, or debt reduction - often at a lower effective cost of capital than borrowing. They turn real estate into a strategic asset without losing operational control.

text:
You may not have heard of Golden Chick, but this 240+ location Southern fried chicken chain is proving that staying local, scrappy, and true to your roots can lead to massive growth.

And it’s quietly proving that being small, scrappy, and regional can be its biggest advantage.

Started in 1967 by a WWII vet in a tiny Texas town, Golden Chick was a family-run operation with a secret recipe and a dream.

Fast forward to today, and it’s a 240+ location chain that generated $306M in sales last year

The secret? They’ve stuck to what works:  
- Marinating their chicken for 24 hours
- Focusing on drive-thru-friendly, comfort food menus that crushed it during COVID
- Expanding methodically by doubling down on their core markets in the South  

They *do* have something those big guys can’t replicate:
- A loyal following of families, franchisees, and fans who feel like they’re part of something local
- And a brand that’s stayed true to its Southern roots.  

In a world of fast-scaling startups and everywhere-all-at-once growth, Golden Chick is proof that there’s power in knowing your niche and playing the long game.

We’re building Superorder for the scrappy, resilient businesses like Golden Chick -- so operators can focus on what they do best while we handle keeping the guests happy 💛

Thank you Brian Loescher, Howard Terry, Cynthia Loescher, Shelby Shipley, and Madison Salazar!

text:
Sweetgreen is in a tough spot right now

But they’re holding a move that could flip the game overnight.

Losses are deepening, same-store sales are down, and customer traffic is eroding in key markets. But there’s a bright spot: The Infinite Kitchen.

Sweetgreen’s Q2 2025 results paint a challenging picture:

📉 $23.2M net loss, up from $14.5M a year ago.
📉 7.6% drop in same-store sales – their second consecutive quarterly decline (but H1 2025 has been down for the industry overall)
📉 6.5% fall in customer traffic, especially in core urban markets like NYC, LA, and Boston.
📉 Operational margin sliding to –14.2% from –8.8% last year, weighed down by menu complexity and high overhead.

Operationally, things were also tough:
Loyalty program transition – from Sweetpass to a new points-based SG Rewards – disrupted buying patterns: fewer repeat visits from regular customers.
Distractions from the short-lived Ripple Fries launch (discontinued after a few months)

But their Infinite Kitchen pilot locations show signs of promise

These automated, AI-powered kitchens are delivering ~28% store-level margins – a meaningful jump from the chain’s typical 18–22% range.

If you look at the chart below (indexed to a ~$16 bowl):
$16.00 in revenue 
$12.86 in restaurant operating costs
Leaves:
~ $3.14 in restaurant gross margins (~20%)

If margins are getting to ~28%, that's an additional $1.28 (8% of $16), mostly coming out of the $4.46 labor cost.

That’s a ~29% reduction in labor costs!

Sweetgreen still faces headwinds, but Infinite Kitchen shows a clear path to scaling profitability without relying solely on price hikes.

If it can be rolled out systemwide, Sweetgreen’s margin profile could change dramatically.

text:
Have you heard of the quick service chain doing ~$200M a year selling spam and rice?

This is the story of L&L Hawaiian Barbecue

Year 1 (1952): Founded as L&L Dairy in Honolulu, Hawaii (evolved from a dairy shop to a soda bar and finally a drive-in restaurant)

Year 24 (1976): Acquired by Eddie Flores Jr. and Johnson Kam, who reimagined it as a plate lunch chain and kept it in the family ever since

Year 36 (1988): Began franchising, expanding beyond Hawaii – 30 locations by 1997
  
Year 47 (1999): Opened first mainland location in the City of Industry, California, rebranded as L&L Hawaiian Barbecue.  

Year 67 (2019): Leadership transitioned to Elisia Flores (Eddie’s daughter), focusing on International growth as well (launched in Japan).

From one small diner in 1952 to 230+ locations today, they’ve nailed franchising:  
- Low franchise royalties (3-4%) 💰 
- Low initial capital required ($250k)

And it’s paying off:
📌 From 200 locations in 2019 to 235 by mid-2025 – a ~17.5% increase in units -- they’ve been growing steadily.
📌 Same-store sales rose 7.3% in 2024, proving their ability to scale while growing 3x the national average of 1.6%

Excited to see what the next decade holds for L&L and super excited to have them on board!

Elisia Flores L&L Hawaiian Barbecue Kyler Kokubun Troy Oshimo

text:
🚨🚨🚨 CAVA now has their very own labubus rolling out TODAY!!

Today, CAVA will launch its first-ever meal box -- the Hot Harissa Meal -- with a Harissa Avocado Bowl, Hot Harissa Pita Chips… and a PLUSH TOY.

Not just any plush toy: a pita chip character designed by creator Thaddeus Coates (a.k.a. Hippy Potter), inspired by the viral Pop Mart Labubu collectibles.

Here’s how it works:
Four characters  --  “Peter Chip,” “Garlic Gus,” “Jimmy Harissa,” and “Sweet Sammy.”
Blind box model  --  you won’t know which you get until you open the meal.
Limited run  --  only available in-restaurant, for a short time.
Each plush comes on a keyring, perfect for attaching to a bag and showing off online.

The entire campaign is designed to capitalize on the massive Labubu trend of collectible, wearable toys, only a few months after the trend started on social media.

Why Labubu matters:

🌏 Originated with Pop Mart (Beijing toy company), gaining global fame after K-pop star Lisa (Blackpink) was seen with one in April 2024.  
🎶 Endorsed by Rihanna, Cher, and others.  
💥 Sold out so quickly they crashed Pop Mart’s website and caused store fights in the UK.  
🧸 Positioned between toys and fashion -- like Jellycat (if you don’t know ask someone under the age of 25), but with an edgy “ugly-cute” vibe.  
📈 Even counterfeit “Lafufu” versions are gaining attention in this booming market.

Here’s where this has happened before.

McDonald’s collectibles prove this model works:
Teenie Beanie Babies (1997–2000)  --  Some rare singles now fetch thousands; complete sets sell for $800+.
Furby Toy Sets (1990s)  --  Full sets have sold for ~$1,000.
101 Dalmatians Collector Box Set  --  Worth $50–$380 today.
Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Set  --  Up to $120 for a full set.

In fact, you could argue that Furby was the Labubu of the 90's!

This is a good strategy for CAVA.

📈 FOMO drives foot traffic  --  The blind-box format makes repeat visits more likely (“gotta collect them all”).  
💬 Social amplification  --  Building on cultural cachet instead of having to manufacture their own  
🎁 Emotional connection  --  The plushies become a tangible, lasting reminder of the brand

There is one difference here:

McDonalds and others often licensed the actual toy / brand.

It looks like CAVA didn’t want the overhead and instead decided to roll out their own line of toys

The upside is it’s likely faster and CAVA has full creative control. The downside is that consumers might not care as much as they do about “authentic” Labubus.

Opportunities for brands to be relevant are scarce

It will be interesting to see how this strategy performs for CAVA.

text:
Did you know that every person at McDonalds might be paying a different price for the same meal?

Here’s how it works: 
A McChicken costs $4.09 at the counter. 
On the McDonald’s app, you get a 50% discount (usable once a day!)

20-piece nuggets are $9.69 in-store. 
Use the app, and they’re $5 off (~50%)

McDonald’s is building a complex price discrimination engine –   
They’re segmenting customers based on behavior and willingness to pay. 

Late-night crowd, too tired to open the app? Pay full price  
Price-sensitive customers can get a discount -- but only through the app. 

Other benefits:
👉 Localized campaigns (eg free fries when local teams win)
👉 Notifications direct to customer phones
👉 Every tap on the app is free customer intent data

McDonalds stock is up 55% in the last 5 years, and pricing strategy is definitely a driver of that.

Competing with Starbucks and Dunkin’ is a fool's errand but Biggby Coffee has opened 430+ locations to take them on over the last 30 years. 

While the big players focus on scale, Biggby is leaning into human connection:  
- A fully franchised model empowering local owners to invest in their communities
- Partnerships with farmers (currently Jinotega, Nicaragua and Ndola, Zambia)

Biggby Coffee isn’t the only player making moves in the massive coffee market:

- Scooter’s Coffee added 300 stores in 24 months, now at 800 units (~25% growth p.a.), with a focus on fast service (under 2 minutes) and a consistent drive-thru format. 

- Dutch Bros leverages flavor-forward drinks to fuel rapid expansion, targeting 2,029 stores by 2029 (doubling their current ~1k locations) 

- Black Rifle Coffee Company’s wholesale-first strategy (eg Walmart, Sam’s Club)  is also delivering DTC, with $245M in sales in 2024 and a pause on new store builds

- Philz Coffee takes a slower approach with just 75 stores focused on high-touch, one-cup-at-a-time service. They’re much smaller but have a loyal base in California

These brands are proving there’s no one-size-fits-all approach to success in the $54B coffee industry.

Biggby now has over 430 locations across 13 states and is opening 35+ more by the end of 2025.

Scooter's Coffee BIGGBY COFFEE Dutch Bros Coffee Black Rifle Coffee Company

text:
California is running a real-time experiment for the restaurant industry 👇  

The state’s $20/hour minimum wage for fast-food workers took effect in April 2025
Here’s what’s happening on the ground:  

1️⃣ Menus are getting pricier—fast.
- Chipotle’s California menu is up ≈ 6-7%.
- A 27-chain scan by Datassential shows statewide fast-food prices +13.1% YoY – nearly 2× the rest of the U.S.
- One Los Angeles McDonald’s operator lifted prices 8-10 % and now reports -16 % sales/traffic. Placer.ai data echoes the trend: statewide McD foot-traffic flipped from slightly above the U.S. average to -2.5 pp below after April 1.

2️⃣ Automation is filling the gap (slowly).
- White Castle still plans ~100 Flippy fry robots (≈ ⅓ of its system), but SEC filings show only 13 units live across White Castle and Jack in the Box today. The newest model installs in hours, ~75 % faster than the prior generation.
- Kiosks are scaling faster than robots: Jack in the Box has added self-order kiosks to 1,500 stores, and a 180-unit Burger King/Popeyes franchisee is retrofitting every location within 60 days.

3️⃣ Schedules are slimming down.
- An Orange-County Wendy’s cut day-shift crews from ≈ 11 to 7 workers.
- Employment Policies Institute survey: 89 % of California operators have trimmed hours and 98% have raised prices since April.

4️⃣ The price gap keeps widening.
Limited-service menu inflation in California (13.1%) is almost double the national rate (7.2%), nudging some diners toward groceries or full-service restaurants.

Bottom line: The $20 wage hasn’t collapsed the industry, but it’s forcing radical re-thinks in pricing, staffing, and automation – moves happening sooner and harder than anywhere else. Every brand CFO and every state legislature now has a front-row seat to California’s experiment.

text:
Why Cava is worth billions but your local restaurant struggles: assembly lines vs. cooking.

Here's what you see at Cava:
- Pre-cut vegetables in measured portions
- Staff following exact assembly protocols
- Zero cooking decisions or creativity
- Standardized portions down to the gram
- Same experience in every location

Here's what happens at your local restaurant:
- Chef decides seasoning levels daily
- Portion sizes vary by cook
- "A little extra" or "light on the sauce"
- Different results every time
- Creativity and variation

Cava model:
- Hires quickly, train in 2 days
- No culinary skills required
- Predictable food costs
- Scalable to 1,000+ locations
- Consistent profit margins

Local restaurant model:
- Hire experienced cooks slowly
- Long training periods
- Variable food costs
- Chef creativity = cost variations
- Margins depend on who's cooking

This is why franchises dominate: McDonald's, Chipotle, Subway sell assembly-line consistency, not just food.

The most successful "restaurants" eliminated cooking entirely. They're manufacturing operations with customer-facing assembly.

Your local chef's creativity is most often their competitive disadvantage. Every variation costs money, creates inconsistency, and makes scaling impossible.

Operators who adapt *fast* are the ones who win.

In restaurants, speed and format matter just as much as flavor.
Especially when some customers are deciding from the driver’s seat.

text:
Chili’s just grew same-store sales +31% in one quarter.  

🍔 McDonald’s: down 3.6%.
☕️ Starbucks: down 2%.  
🌯 Chipotle: down 0.4%.
🌶️ Chili’s? Up 31%.

How?

Chili’s wasn’t interested in small improvement – they went back to the drawing board.
1️⃣ Their $10 “3 for Me” deal gave diners an affordable, clear reason to visit – 21 % year-over-year traffic surge, with management crediting value-focused ads that pit 3 for Me against fast-food pricing.
2️⃣ They revamped kitchen processes with TurboChef ovens (MSRP >$10k), speeding up service and flipping tables faster.  The technology cuts cook times 40–50%
3️⃣ And they simplified the menu, making operations leaner and the customer experience smoother. Over the last 2½ years Chili’s has removed ~25 % of its menu, doubling down on its “core four” (burgers, crispers, fajitas, margaritas) which now account for 47% of sales

It wasn’t just about cutting costs. It was about delivering more value. 

When the market shifts, the winners are the ones who keep experimenting.

text:
The restaurant industry has been through hell and back. But resilience is paying off 👇

After a year of closures and bankruptcies, the full-service segment is stabilizing.  

Chains like Red Lobster, TGI Fridays, and Denny’s shut down dozens of locations. Yet, visits per location stayed flat (+0.2%).

Here's what's happening across the board:

📉 Quick service is down – consumers are bored of legacy brands and craving novelty (Subway shuttered 631 U.S. restaurants in 2024; KFC is testing the comeback of its classic “Twister” wraps in Nashville to reignite buzz)

📈 Fast casual is up – people want healthier, diverse meals without the formality and overhead (Digital orders made up 35.4 % of Chipotle’s Q1-2025 revenue; salad-focused Chopt is on track to hit ≈100 units this year, up from 88 in 2023 — about 14 % growth)

📉 Casual / full-service is down – middle-tier dining feels overpriced in an inflation-weary world (Olive Garden’s same-restaurant sales fell 2.9 % in its latest quarter despite promos; BJ’s is leaning on a $13 “Pizookie Meal Deal” value bundle to pull guests back)

📈 Fine dining is up – if you’re going out less, make it count with a special experience (Tasting-menu 
prices keep climbing: Atelier Crenn now charges $410+ per person, while Restaurant Daniel’s seven-course menu sits at $295, both all-time highs for those rooms)

📈 Coffee is way up – coffee shops are the new third space for work, dates, and everything in-between (Blank Street nearly doubled to 84 cafés over the past 12 months; Blue Bottle is approaching the 100-store mark worldwide and just entered Singapore with its first Southeast-Asia café)

The restaurant landscape is shifting, but the opportunity is there for operators who adapt quickly.

text:
I studied 500+ restaurants, and all of the successful restaurants had one thing in common: 

They are obsessed with the boring details.

They make millions by crushing the basics, not chasing trends.

What they actually focus on:
- Checking food temps every 30 minutes
- Responding to every review within 24 hours
- Cleaning equipment the exact same way daily
- Training staff on portion control to the gram
- Double-checking every delivery bag before it leaves

What everyone else focuses on:
- New menu items
- Instagram-worthy decor
- Celebrity chef partnerships
- Trendy marketing campaigns

The boring truth is that success is 10% innovation and 90% execution.

Champions turn mundane tasks into unfair advantages. While rivals hunt viral moments, they master fundamentals.

Michael Phelps nailed it:
“The one thing that’s common to all successful people: They make a habit of doing things that unsuccessful people don’t like to do.”

Focus on the laps that matter.

text:
Surprisingly, the #1 reason restaurants fail is not what you think.

I have gone through thousands of delivery reviews, and missing items kill restaurants faster than bad food.

The typical scenario: Customer orders 5 items, receives 4. 

They paid $60, got $45 worth of food, and now they're furious.

Why this destroys restaurants:
- Customers blame the restaurant, not the driver
- Missing items feel like theft, not mistakes
- One missing item ruins the entire meal experience
- Refunds eat into already thin delivery margins

What's really happening: 

Restaurants designed for dine-in are failing at delivery logistics. 

Kitchen staff aren't trained to double-check bags. No systems exist to verify orders before they leave.

The brutal math: A $15 missing item creates a $60 refund demand plus a 1-star review that costs thousands in future revenue.

What successful restaurants do: Checklists for every order. Dedicated delivery stations. Staff trained specifically for packaging accuracy.

The restaurants who are winning delivery are not serving better food. 

They are just not forgetting the fries :)

text:
Ever wonder why Krispy Kreme feels more relevant today? In 2009 they faced a dilemma and emerged stronger than ever.

1️⃣ Cut the bloat.
 - Cut under-performing stores – 29 U.S. shops were shuttered or converted in 2023
 - Focus on the Original Glazed – 20% of low-velocity SKUs were dropped in the 2020-21 reset
 - Shift to franchising to stabilize cash flow — 119 company-owned shops were sold to franchisees in 2022, taking the domestic mix to >40 % franchised

2️⃣ Instead of building expensive flagship bakeries…
 - Build massive doughnut kitchens –  232 Hot-Light Theater hubs (with the classic Krispy Kreme conveyor belt) that bake for the whole network
 - Send fresh batches daily to kiosks in big-box stores and grocery chains — the hubs restock ~6,700 daily “points of access” (grocery, gas, Walmart, until recently McDonalds, etc.)

3️⃣ Build your brand for the social media era
 - Free doughnuts for healthcare workers during COVID: 30 million doughnuts given to frontline workers in 2020
 - Seasonal glazes and pop-culture tie-ins = constant buzz - “Dolly Southern Sweets” four-flavor collab sold out in <48h and trended on U.S. food Twitter

By 2023, Krispy Kreme grew revenue 3x without losing what made them special. Fresh, hot doughnuts, always where the customer is.

text:
Chick-fil-A earns $8.5M per store. Subway? $500K. Here's the thing franchise owners miss.

Chick-fil-A keeps tight control:  
- Fewer stores (2,500 vs. Subway's 20,000)
- Mandatory owner-operators (no absentee owners) – if you own it, you're in the restaurant   
- Prospective owners must have been Chick‑fil‑A managers
- Real estate & build-out controlled by franchisor: They own the property and equipment, leasing it to you  –  giving them full scope over site, design and brand consistency

Subway's model? 
- Subway actively recruits owners to hold multi locations – often 25+ units. This encourages passive investors who can oversee many units rather than deeply engage with individual restaurants.
- Franchisees lease and renovate their own real estate and choose their layouts—unlike Chick‑fil‑A's full franchisor-controlled build-out.
- Oversaturation → cannibalization: Subway's Average Unit Volume increased until 2013, then dropped sharply likely because stores placed too close to existing franchises were cannibalizing sales

The result?
Subway's revenue peaked in 2013 and never recovered.
Chick-fil-a's revenue has more than DOUBLED in the same period.

analysis.howItMadeReadersFeel: Shocked by the 17x difference ($8.5M vs $500K). Made them feel informed about hidden franchise mechanics they didn't know existed. Gave them insider knowledge on why Chick-fil-A dominates.
analysis.whatTheyLearned: Specific control mechanisms that create the revenue gap: owner-operator requirements, real estate control, franchise density management. Learned that Subway's multi-unit model actually causes cannibalization.
analysis.whyShareableOrNot: Highly shareable - makes you look sophisticated about franchise economics. Gives you specific talking points (the control mechanisms) to reference in conversations. Shows you understand business models at a deep level.
analysis.whatWorkedOrDidntWork: The $8.5M vs $500K hook was everything - immediately grabbed attention and created massive curiosity gap about WHY such a huge difference exists. Side-by-side comparison made it scannable and easy to digest.

leverageSignals.note: $8.5M vs $500K = 17x gap. This hook is everything - immediately stops scrolling, shows dominance, and creates irresistible curiosity about the mechanism behind the difference.

Layered drinks.
Cold foam on top.
Flavors like Brown Sugar, Strawberry Matcha, and Salted Caramel Mocha.

It’s a smart move to get customers back in stores and create buzz online and create free word-of-mouth.  

Your menu is more than what you serve. It’s a marketing tool.

text:
There’s FEMA. There’s NOAA. And then there’s Waffle House.

Emergency responders have an unofficial rule of thumb: check the Waffle House Index.

Waffle House doesn’t close.
If it does, everyone knows: the disaster is real.

A Waffle House open with a full menu? Green.
Running on generators with a limited menu? Yellow.
Closed? Red. That means something went very, very wrong.

I’ve always loved the clarity of that.
Simple. Real-world.

And it actually makes sense.
In a crisis, restaurants become gathering points, information hubs, places of calm.
In tough times, it’s the essentials – and the people who show up to serve them – that hold the line

text:
Most restaurants are still built like it’s 2005.
But they're missing an enormous change.

As of 2024, delivery is over 50% of their revenue.

So when we started Superorder, our thesis was simple:
Most restaurants aren’t built for delivery.

- 70% of the space is still tables and chairs.
- Delivery drivers push past diners
- Staff juggles guests, apps, phone orders, etc.

But after working with hundreds of restaurants, we realized the real threat wasn’t the kitchen.

It was reviews. Most owners didn’t know how to win online -- 
No reviews strategy, no post-order engagement.

So we pivoted – today, Superorder helps restaurants own their digital presence -- reviews, reputation, and repeat customers.

text:
A 0.4-star difference just cost this restaurant half a million dollars. 
Yep, you read that right.

The difference between a 4.2-star and 4.6-star restaurant is $500,000 in annual revenue.

I've analyzed thousands of restaurant reviews and their corresponding revenue data. The pattern is shocking.

Here's the math: A restaurant making $5M annually loses half a million dollars just from having 4.2 stars instead of 4.6 stars. 

That's a 10-12% revenue difference.

Why this happens:
Google and Apple Maps both filter out restaurants under 4.5 stars. 
Most people (including me) skip anything below 4.5 when choosing where to eat.

The brutal reality: Restaurant owners hate Yelp and Google reviews. 
They think it's unfair that strangers control their business, but ignoring reviews is like ignoring your P&L.

What kills reviews fastest:
Missing items in delivery orders
Soggy food from poor packaging
Complaints about food quality (if 60-70% of reviews mention bad food, the restaurant is doomed)

The most successful restaurant operators I know obsess over their reviews. 

They respond to everyone. They fix packaging. They train staff differently.

And that’s because they understand that in 2025, your star rating IS your revenue.

text:
There are lessons that every restaurant owner knows
That a Harvard MBA can’t tell you:

Your supply chain isn’t resilient until Sysco shorts you.
Your service doesn’t matter if your Google rating drops below 4.0.
Your margins aren’t real until the delivery platform refunds 15 orders (and you eat the cost)

These folks don’t have the safety nets of VC funding
No CFO. No consultants. No second chances.

They memorize wage laws across counties.
They know if it’ll be a slow night just by looking at the parking lot.
They manage teenagers, landlords, and DoorDash all at once.

And they still make payroll.
Still feed the neighborhood.
Still open again at 7am.

We’re building Superorder for the owners who don’t have time to think about Google, Yelp, Doordash, Uber Eats, and Grubhub ratings and reviews -- but still need to win. If that sounds like you, we’d love to chat.

text:
Your restaurant is bleeding money.

But your vendors won't let you see where it's going.

A restaurant owner I spoke with last month in Las Vegas' Food on Demand shared a common frustration: they couldn't track their vendor costs.

"We might be paying too much in taxes, rent, royalties, and advertising," they said. Even with an accounting background, they couldn't make the numbers add up.

Sound familiar?

Here's the truth: Many vendors deliberately make it hard to see the full financial picture. They bury fees. Obscure costs. Create confusion.

This hits restaurants hardest.

You're running on razor-thin margins already. As my customer said, "it's a pennies game." When you can't track every penny going to vendors, those pennies turn into thousands before you notice.

I've seen it happen. $25K gone because of hidden fees. $2.3M in unnecessary vendor costs over three years.

Not because restaurant owners are careless. But because the system is designed to keep you in the dark.

The solution?

1. Partner only with vendors who provide complete financial transparency
2. Implement systems that show every transaction clearly
3. Walk away from any vendor who makes it difficult to access your own financial data

In 2023, financial transparency isn't a luxury. It's a necessity.

Don't let vendors hide your money from you.

Btw, at Superorder, we built our platform specifically to give restaurant owners full visibility into every transaction. Check out the link under my name if you're tired of vendors hiding your money from you.

Maanav P. Sterling Douglass Andrew N. Restaurant365

text:
Stadium deals crush restaurant brands. Not enhance them.

I talked to a restaurant exec last week who blew my mind with the truth about stadium partnerships.

Everyone sees stadiums as the holy grail of restaurant expansion. Big crowds. Massive exposure. Guaranteed foot traffic.

But reality hits different.

Here's the problem:

When you partner with stadium vendors like Aramark, you surrender the one thing that matters most - your people.

You hand your brand to strangers who don't live your values or understand your standards. They're trained in days, not months.

The exec I spoke with managed 30+ restaurants and saw this pattern repeatedly: Stadium locations consistently delivered subpar food and disappointing experiences.

The real damage?

Those terrible stadium experiences actually stopped customers from visiting their regular locations.

That's right. The "exposure" actively hurt their business.

Her solution was brilliant:

Build full-service restaurants near stadiums instead.

This preserves total control over quality, training, and customer experience.

The numbers backed her up. Their stadium-adjacent locations outperformed the in-stadium counters by 37% in customer satisfaction.

Growth that damages your brand isn't growth at all.

Weak hook means most people keep scrolling before getting to the interesting insight.

Interesting idea but lacks concrete proof with named winners/losers.

text:
"What's the actual dollar value of a star rating?"

A restaurant owner asked me this yesterday.

I love questions that get straight to the point.

So I showed him the cold, hard numbers.

We partnered with a restaurant group that jumped from 3.9 to 4.7 stars.

The impact?
- 8% jump in direct digital sales
- 6x increase in Google Business Profile engagement

Not vanity metrics.

Cash in the register.

But measuring success means focusing on the right numbers.

Stop tracking metrics that don't matter.

Track these 5 indicators instead:

1/ Top-line sales growth from new customers
2/ Digital ordering volume 
3/ Store location searches
4/ Direction requests
5/ Direct phone calls

Better ratings = more orders = more revenue.

Superorder helps restaurants turn ratings into revenue. Check out the link in my profile if you're ready to see the numbers behind your reputation.
